name: Dead Rising 2: Off the Record
description: You are Frank West – photojournalist and original hero of the Dead Rising Willamette incident – taking center stage experiencing the re-imagined Fortune City outbreak.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista®/XP, Windows 7 Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo 2.4 Ghz or better, AMD Athlon X2 2.2 Ghz or better Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA® GeForce® 8800GTS or better, ATI Radeon™ HD 3850 or better DirectX®: DirectX® 9.0c or greater Hard Drive: 8.5 GB free hard drive space Sound: Standard audio device

reviews.review_text: Dead Rising 2: Off The Record is a hard game to judge. Dead Rising 2 was a good game, the problem with Dead Rising 2 is that it's the same game. By that I don't mean 'Oh they reused the assets' or 'They used the same map'. Both of those are acceptable. No Dead Rising 2: Off the Record, literally did a character swap and changed less than a third of the story.   To be honest, this should not have been it's own game. This is almost DLC masquerading as a full release. There is some other changes (a few more survivors, a few changes to survivors, I think a few new psychopaths) but if you've played Dead Rising 2 right before this game, this is going to be like a second playthrough of Dead Rising.   As for the story, there's really two major changes that I noticed. Instead of Chuck being blamed for releasing zombies, another person is blamed. (A character that appears in the original game). And the ending. The final boss, (literally the final scene) is different, with a significantly change to the ending.   There is one new (and rather large) area that is added to the game, that is a nice addition, but it's just that, an addition, not a whole new world.   Other than that, the game, majority of psychopathes and majority of the mall is the same. You're seeing similar people doing similar things, and fighting similar enemies.   So there's really three ways to look at it.   If you played Dead Rising 1 and want to play Dead Rising 2, I would recommend Off The Record, over Dead Rising 2.  If you played Dead Rising 2, you likely will not want to play Off The Record.  If you played Dead Rising 2 but the whole time thought 'I want to play as Frank West' Then Dead Rising 2 Off the Record is for you.   It's not a BAD game, it's fully functional, vastly improves on Dead Rising 2 (You don't have to stand still to talk to Otis, who is not in this version, you get a really functional ear piece as well). The achievements are better as well, the game works well, and you don't have to constantly return to the hideout to give Zombrex to Katie (what an awful gameplay element that was).   If you don't have Dead Rising 2, this is the better version. If you do... I find it hard to recommend this version as you already have a working game. It's not a bad, and I can't not recommend Dead Rising 2: Off the Record because it does nothing wrong. But it is quite a bit of a cash grab for Capcom, and honestly they could have told an all new story. A shame, because this is a rather fun series.   Still I had a blast replaying Dead Rising 2 as I played it when it first came out, and for that. Off the Record delivered exactly what it promised. A retelling of Dead Rising 2 with a new main character.
You should've seen Frank back in his carpenter days. He's covered floors you know.

Sanbox much is incredibly fun, no time limit, no obtaining Zombrex for Frank, just pure unhindered fun.  If you have a friend, it can be much more fun.  The story mode is the exact same from the original Dead Rising 2, just with some minor differences, like the intro, rather than having Frank competing in TIR in the slicycle challenge, you're competing in a wrestling minigame which teaches you the basics of the game and other dialouge in cutscenes.   A great change though is the co-op mode.  In the original Dead Rising 2, if you had someone join, there would be 2 Chuck Greene's.  In DR2 Off the Record, player one is Frank West, player 2 is Chuck Greene and like in Case West, they don't get on well on at all.  Example. Frank tries on a new outfit 'I look hot' and if Chuck is nearby 'You look stupid'.    I'd highly recommend it with a friend.

He's covered wars y'know? Frank West is back, and he is fatter and more out of shape than ever! This game takes the prestine gameplay of Dead Rising 2, and spices it up with a bit of Frank West. In this game, you play in an alternate 'what if' version of Dead Rising 2, where you play as everyones favorite fighting (ex-)photojournalist Frank West. It depicts Frank after the Willimette mall incident, having become overweight and bankrupt, due to the overexposure to the limelight. He is participating in the Terror Is Reality zombie killing game show, in order to net some cash, and get himself back on the map. Unfortunately, there seems to be trouble brewing in the bowels of Fortune City, as Frank finds himself in the middle of another Zombie outbreak. It is up to you, as Frank, to find the truth, and save as many survivors as you can. The gameplay is identical to that of Dead Rising 2, with a few improvements to animation, as well as more missions, bosses, and ways to kill. There is nothing but praise I can give to this game, try it out for yourself, you won't regret it. Dead Rising 2: Off The Record gets an 8.5/10. This game lost a point due to a few side missions that glitched for me, making them unplayable.

This game is so much better than the original Dead Rising in pretty much every aspect. Gameplay is more fun because of the bigger variety in weapons, the combat feels less clunky overall, the game has a better setting making it more fun to explore the area and there is more variety to the environments visually and there is a much higher level of interaction with the world with just more items to interact with in general. The survivors ai is by far the biggest improvement, it’s actually good. They follow you pretty well and their pathfinding is pretty good too. I hated Frank West in the original but In this game he is far less annoying and cringe worthy making him at least bearable. The dialogue, voiceacting and plot is also now bearable which it wasn’t in the original for me. It’s not a good story by any means but it is far better than the original. I think this is a good and very fun zombie game. It’s one of those sequels that does exactly what sequels should do which is improve on every aspect of the original.  7/10 (Good)

Didn't play DR2 so no comparisons to the original can be made.  Played co-op online with my boyfriend and this game is a good 15 hours for a single playthough. Many silly items can be combined and much zombies are there to be killed. The game ran just fine on my 3.2ghz *6 / HD6850 / 8gb RAM system. No hiccups despite tons of zombies, and environments looked fine.. Netplay handled lag quite well. Controls are slightly weird and can't be rebound but the defaults were not troublesome enough to make me gripe.  The game does a good job of giving you pacing with optional quests to save survivors. You dont have a moment to easily breathe unless you are okay with letting a survivor die or missing a bossfight (but they are only worth EXP, so not completely necessary). I'd say the theme of the first game was more interesting, but this one was fun to play and of course had co-op unlike the prequel.
